user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_ip_count_lock:
```c
static void
MHD_ip_count_lock (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->master);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->per_ip_connection_mutex);
#else
  (void) daemon;
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
MHD_ip_count_lock (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The function takes &daemon->per_ip_connection_mutex and passes it to a lock routine, which requires a mutable mutex object; the pointer must therefore be to a non-const struct so that the mutex member can be modified. Rule 8.13 recommends const-qualified pointers when possible, but in this case the pointed-to object (the mutex) is modified, so a non-const pointer is appropriate.
